messages.content:
You are an AI assistant specialized in analyzing web projects developed using PHP and the Laravel 11.x (laravel/framework ^11.28) framework. I need to generate an OpenAPI Specification for a web project based on its backend source code. I'm now focusing on endpoint `/v1/comments` with method GET, and here is the relevant information I found:

1. In `app/Http/Controllers/Api/V1/CommentController.php`, `CommentController` is implemented to process HTTP requests to `/v1/comments` with HTTP method GET.

2. In `app/Http/Controllers/Api/V1/CommentController.php`, `App\\Http\\Controllers\\Api\\V1\\CommentController@index` is implemented to process HTTP requests to `/v1/comments` with HTTP method GET.

I'll provide you with the contents of the files mentioned above, you have the option to execute additional Unix commands to gather more information if necessary, but you must not run the source code of the project, and your task is to generate a list of Parameter Objects (the value of paths.[endpoint].[method].parameters) in Swagger 2.0 format.

You need to think step by step and provide an explanation of your results first. Then, output exactly "the final generated result begins", followed by the list of Parameter Objects in JSON format. Do not include fields not mentioned above, and do not use references ($ref) in your output (try to obtain the structure by executing additional Unix commands).

function.name: run_command
function.description: Run a Unix command and get outputs in the project directory. You must not run any source code of the project.

message.content:
Explanation of how I derived the parameters

- I inspected app/Http/Controllers/Api/V1/CommentController.php. The index method is:
  return CommentResource::collection(
      Comment::latest()->paginate($request->input('limit', 20))
  );
  This shows the controller accepts a query parameter named "limit" (with default 20) which controls the pagination size.

- Laravel's paginator uses the "page" query parameter to select the current page when paginate() is used. Although the controller does not explicitly read "page", clients can pass ?page=<n> to navigate pages produced by paginate(). Therefore the endpoint accepts a "page" query parameter as well.

- The GET /v1/comments route is declared in routes/api.php as a public route (index and show are exposed without auth middleware in the routes file), so no required Authorization parameter is implied by the controller itself.

- Based on Swagger 2.0 Parameter Object structure for query parameters, I included:
  - "limit": query parameter, integer, default 20, optional — controls items per page.
  - "page": query parameter, integer, default 1, optional — selects the page number.

the final generated result begins
[
  {
    "name": "limit",
    "in": "query",
    "description": "Number of comments per page (pagination size). Defaults to 20.",
    "required": false,
    "type": "integer",
    "format": "int32",
    "default": 20
  },
  {
    "name": "page",
    "in": "query",
    "description": "Page number for pagination. When omitted defaults to the first page.",
    "required": false,
    "type": "integer",
    "format": "int32",
    "default": 1
  }
]
